example: After the reorganization, the director's span of control increased from five to ten direct reports.

definition: The process of aligning an organization's human capital with its strategic goals to ensure it has the right people, with the right skills, in the right roles at the right time.
example: Our Strategic Workforce Management initiative identified a future need for data scientists, so we're starting to recruit and train for those skills now.

definition: A project or task given to an employee that is beyond their current knowledge or skill level, designed to challenge them and develop new abilities.
example: To prepare her for a leadership role, her manager gave her a stretch assignment leading the new product launch.

definition: An interviewing method where all candidates are asked the same set of predetermined questions to ensure fairness and consistency in the evaluation process.
example: By using structured interviewing, the hiring team could objectively compare each candidate's answers to the same competency-based questions.

definition: A model visualizing the recruitment process from a candidate's first point of contact (awareness) to their eventual hire, helping to track and optimize each stage.
example: We're losing too many good applicants after the first interview; we need to analyze our talent acquisition funnel to identify the problem.

definition: The proactive process of identifying and building relationships with potential candidates for critical roles, even before a specific job opening exists.
example: Instead of waiting for a vacancy, our talent pipelining efforts ensure we have a pool of qualified software engineers ready to engage.

definition: The complete pay an employee receives in a year, which includes their base salary plus any short-term cash incentives like bonuses or commissions.
example: While the base salary is competitive, the performance bonus makes the Total Cash Compensation for this sales role very attractive.

definition: A program designed to make employees aware of their hidden, automatic biases so they can make more objective decisions, particularly in hiring and promotions.
example: After the mandatory unconscious bias training, managers were more mindful of their assumptions during performance reviews.

definition: An action by an employer or union that violates labor laws, such as interfering with employees' rights to organize or bargain collectively.
example: Firing an employee for trying to start a union was ruled an Unfair Labor Practice by the National Labor Relations Board.

definition: Legal safeguards that protect employees from retaliation after reporting illegal, unsafe, or unethical practices within their organization.
example: The company's whistleblower protection policy ensures that anyone reporting financial misconduct can do so without fear of losing their job.

definition: A formal process of gathering facts to determine if a complaint of misconduct, such as harassment or discrimination, has occurred in the workplace.
example: HR has launched a confidential workplace investigation following the anonymous complaint filed last week.

definition: The practice of using data and statistical methods to measure, analyze, and improve the performance and management of an organization's workforce.
example: Using workforce analytics, we discovered a direct correlation between employee engagement scores and departmental productivity.

definition: A software application that manages the entire recruiting and hiring process, from receiving applications to making an offer.
example: Our ATS automatically filters resumes for keywords, saving our recruiters hours of manual screening.

definition: A metric used to measure employee loyalty and engagement by asking how likely they are to recommend their company as a place to work.
example: After the recent changes, our quarterly eNPS dropped by 15 points, so we need to address employee concerns.

definition: A type of employee benefit plan that gives workers an ownership interest in the company through shares of stock.
example: The company's ESOP is a great incentive for long-term retention as it gives staff a real stake in our success.

definition: The unique set of benefits and rewards an employee receives in return for their skills and contributions to a company.
example: Our EVP emphasizes work-life balance and professional development opportunities to attract top candidates.

definition: An HR professional who works directly with a company's leadership to develop and direct an HR strategy that aligns with business goals.
example: I've scheduled a meeting with our HRBP to discuss the staffing needs for the new marketing project.

definition: A broad set of practices for recruiting, managing, developing, and optimizing employees to increase their value to the organization.
example: Our new HCM software integrates payroll, benefits, and performance management into a single platform.

definition: A software system used to maintain and manage core employee data, such as personal information, roles, and payroll.
example: Please update your contact information directly in the HRIS by the end of the week.

definition: A software application for the administration, tracking, and delivery of educational courses or training programs.
example: All new employees must complete the mandatory compliance training on our LMS within their first 30 days.

definition: A management model that aims to improve performance by clearly defining objectives that are agreed upon by both management and employees.
example: Our company uses an MBO approach, so each team member's goals are directly aligned with the department's key targets.

definition: A formal document outlining specific areas where an employee is underperforming and the steps they must take to improve.
example: After several missed deadlines, John's manager had to put him on a Performance Improvement Plan.

definition: A business model where a company transfers all or part of its recruitment processes to an external provider.
example: To scale up quickly for our expansion, we decided to use an RPO firm to handle all our international hiring.
